conversation.message: Hello Nursery_C, I’m Parent_E. Nursery_C is my first choice, and I’d like to formally apply. I’m very motivated to enroll with you and would happily accept an offer if available.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is Nursery_C, so I should apply there immediately. Although Nursery_C ranks me 4th (behind Parents B, C, D), applying now maximizes my chance before capacity fills and keeps me aligned with my true preferences rather than prematurely compromising.

conversation.message: Thank you for applying, Parent_E. At this time we’re not able to offer you a place, as we need to prioritize other applicants according to our allocation order. I appreciate your interest in Nursery_C and wish you the best in the process.
conversation.thought: Parent_E is applying to us in round 1. On our true priority list, Parent_E ranks 4th (after Parent_B, Parent_C, Parent_D). Given the market, Parent_B’s top choice is Nursery_A (then B, then us), Parent_C’s top choice is Nursery_B (then us), and Parent_D’s top choice is Nursery_B (then us). It is plausible that at least one of B/C/D may come to us in later rounds if rejected elsewhere. With quota 1, accepting Parent_E now would block the chance to match with a higher-priority parent. Since we can’t hold offers and must accept/reject immediately, the best strategy to maximize our outcome is to reject Parent_E now and wait for higher-ranked candidates.

conversation.message: Hello Nursery_B, I’m Parent_A. Nursery_B is my first choice, and I’m applying now because I’m very eager to join your community. If offered a place, I will accept and commit promptly. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is Nursery_B, so I should apply immediately. Although Nursery_B ranks me last in its priority list, delaying would only reduce my chances further if others apply first. An early, committed application is my best shot to secure my first choice.

conversation.thought: Parent_A is last on Nursery_B’s true priority list (E > B > C > D > A). Rejecting Parent_A preserves capacity to accept a higher-priority applicant (ideally Parent_C or Parent_D; Parent_E is top but is unlikely to apply since they rank us last).

Between C and D, Parent_C is ranked higher than Parent_D, and Parent_C also lists Nursery_B as first choice, so accepting D now would risk blocking a better match with C. I should reject Parent_D to preserve the seat for Parent_C (or potentially Parent_B/Parent_E if they approach later).

conversation.thought: My true priority is E > B > C > D > A. In this round I have applications from A, D, and C. Among these, Parent_C is the highest on my list. I already rejected A and D (lower priority than C). With quota 1, accepting C now secures my best available option this round. While Parent_E and Parent_B are higher, neither has applied to me this round, and delaying risks losing C to another nursery (C ranks Nursery_B first, but could move on in later rounds). Therefore accept Parent_C.

conversation.message: Dear Nursery_A, I’m Parent_B and Nursery_A is my first choice. I’m ready to accept a place immediately if offered, and I’m excited about the chance to join your community. Thank you for considering my application.

conversation.message: Dear Parent_B, thank you very much for your application and for placing Nursery_A as your first choice. At this time, we’re not able to offer you a place. We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best with your allocation process.
conversation.thought: Parent_B is applying to us as their 1st choice, but on Nursery_A’s true priority list Parent_B ranks 4th (behind Parent_E, Parent_D, Parent_A). In this market, Parent_E ranks Nursery_A 3rd (after C,D), Parent_D ranks us 3rd (after B,C), and Parent_A ranks us 3rd (after B,C). So higher-priority parents may not come to us immediately, but they could if rejected elsewhere. With quota 1, accepting Parent_B now would block any chance to match with E/D/A later in the process. Since we can reject and keep the seat open, the best strategy to maximize our outcome is to hold out for higher-priority candidates rather than lock in a 4th-choice match in round 1.
